Dealing With Powers and nth roots

Author

Zoe Gemmell

Summary
Simplifying expressions involving powers and \(n\)th roots is a valuable skill to learn. In this guide you will learn a few manipulation techniques that will hopefully be useful going further into your maths career.

Before reading this guide, it is recommended that you read (Guide: Laws of indices). This guide uses \(\cdot\) for multiplication. Power is another word for indice/index.

This guide will focus on expressions with bases and powers. You can recognise them from combinations of expressions in the following format: \[\begin{align*} base^{power} \end{align*}\]

What is a base?

A base is a number that is raised to a power. It can be any number you can think of; single digit, decimal numbers, a million. This is the number that gets multiplied by itself.

What is a power you might then ask? A power is any number that you can raise a base to, it dictates how many times the base is multiplied by itself.

Example 1

\[\begin{align*} 3^5 \textsf{ means } \underbrace{3\cdot3\cdot3\cdot3\cdot3}_{5\,times} \end{align*}\]

You would say this out loud as ‘three multiplied by itself five times’, ‘three to the fifth power’ or ‘three to the five’.

Working with powers - The Definitions

Before you have a look at the laws here are some definitions:

Definition of expression

A mathematical expression is a combination of symbols that has a finite length.

Definition of commutativity

Changing the order of the numbers involved in your expression does not change the answer.

Example 2

\(2+3=5=3+2\)

The order of the 2 and 3 can be swapped and the answer stays the same.

Definition of terminoligy in a fraction

The numerator of a fraction is everything on top of the line, the denominator is everything underneath the line:

\[\begin{align*} \dfrac{numerator}{denominator}\end{align*}\]

Tip

Both addition and multiplication are commutative

Now onto the laws:

Law 7: Multiplication of variables with the same indices but different bases

When multiplying variables with the same powers you can expand and rewrite them into a nicer format:

\[\begin{align*} a^r \cdot b^r = (ab)^r \end{align*}\]

Where the bases are multiplied together then raised to the rth power.

Example 3

\[\begin{align*} 2^3 \cdot 3^3 &= \underbrace{(2\cdot 2\cdot 2)}_{3\,times}\cdot \underbrace{(3\cdot 3\cdot 3)}_{3\,times}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= 2\cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 3\cdot 2 \cdot 3 \tag{\,by commutativity}\\[0.5em] &= (2\cdot 3)^3\nonumber \end{align*}\]

Law 8: Division of variables with the same indices but different bases

When dividing variables with the same powers you can expand and rewrite them into a nicer format:

\[\begin{align*} \dfrac{a^r}{b^r} = (\dfrac{a}{b})^r \end{align*}\]

Where the numerator base (a) is divided by the denominator base (b) then raised to the rth power.

Example 4

\[\begin{align*} \dfrac{4^4}{5^4} &= \dfrac{\overbrace{4\cdot 4\cdot 4\cdot 4}^{4\,times}}{\underbrace{5\cdot 5\cdot 5\cdot 5}_{4\,times}}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= \dfrac{4}{5}\cdot \dfrac{4}{5}\cdot \dfrac{4}{5}\cdot \dfrac{4}{5} \tag{\,by commutativity}\\[0.5em] &= (\dfrac{4}{5})^4 \end{align*}\]

Law 9: fractional power, the nth root

When multiplying by bases with fractional powers (some sort of nth root) :

\[\begin{align*} a^{1/n} \cdot b=\sqrt[n]{a \cdot b^n} \end{align*}\]

Where the aim of the manipulation is to put everything inside the square root sign, then to continue with the calculation.

Example 5

\[\begin{align*} 2^{1/3}\cdot 4 &= 2^{1/3}\cdot 4^{3/3}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= \sqrt[3]{2\cdot 4^3}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= \sqrt[3]{2\cdot (2\cdot 2)^3}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= \sqrt[3]{2^7} \tag{\,$(2^2)^3=2^{2\cdot 3}=2^6$}\\[0.5em] &= 2^{7/3} \end{align*}\]

Law 10: Multiplication under the root sign

When you have a term under a \(n\)th root sign which you can factorise (split up into different factors) this can be done and the \(n\)th root signs can be dealt with separately.

\[\begin{align*} \sqrt[n]{a\cdot b}=\sqrt[n]{a}\cdot\sqrt[n]{b}\end{align*}\]

Where you are using the commutativity of multiplication to split up the \(n\)th root and deal with terms separately.

Example 6

\[\begin{align*} \sqrt{12} &= \sqrt{4\cdot 3}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= \sqrt{4}\cdot\sqrt{3}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= 2\cdot\sqrt{3} \end{align*}\]

Solving equations

Using the laws above you can solve equations

Tip

When dealing with equations, you may find yourself faced with the following form: \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{1}{a+\sqrt{b}}\end{align*}\]

In which case you will want to use the conjugate of the denominator to creatively multiply the fraction by 1. The conjugate of \(a+\sqrt{b}\) is \(a-\sqrt{b}\), to find this for any espression you change the sign in front of the root.

\[\begin{align*} \dfrac{1}{a+\sqrt{b}}\cdot 1&= \dfrac{1}{a+\sqrt{b}}\cdot\dfrac{a-\sqrt{b}}{a-\sqrt{b}}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= \dfrac{a-\sqrt{b}}{(a+\sqrt{b})(a-\sqrt{b})}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= \dfrac{a-\sqrt{b}}{a^2+a\sqrt{b}-a\sqrt{b}-(\sqrt{b})^2}\nonumber \\[0.5em] &= \dfrac{a-\sqrt{b}}{a^2-b} \end{align*}\]

Now the fraction only has square roots in the numerator, this is better because it can often make expressions you are dealing with more concise.

Example 7

\[\begin{align*} 2^{x+1}\cdot 3^x&=72\nonumber \\[0.5em] 2(2\cdot 3)^x&=72\nonumber \\[0.5em] (2\cdot 3)^x&=36\nonumber \\[0.5em] 6^x&=36 \end{align*}\]

From here you can count up powers of 6 to work out the value of x: \(6^1=6\), \(6^2=36\) so \(x=2\)

Example 8

Here is a rather long example using multiple laws from this guide and the intro to indices guide.

\[\begin{align*} \sqrt{(6x)^3}&=8\sqrt{27}\nonumber \\[0.5em] \sqrt{x^3}\cdot\sqrt{6^3}&=8\sqrt{27}\tag{\,Using Law 7 and Law 10} \\[0.5em] \sqrt{x^3}\cdot\sqrt{(2\cdot 3)^3}&=8\sqrt{27}\tag{\,Using Law 7} \\[0.5em] \sqrt{x^3}\cdot\sqrt{2^3}\sqrt{3^3}&=8\sqrt{27}\tag{\,Using Law 10} \\[0.5em] \end{align*}\] to simplify the appearance of the calculation, swap \(2^3\) for \(8\) \[\begin{align*} \sqrt{x^3}\cdot\sqrt{8}\sqrt{27}&=8\sqrt{27}\nonumber \\[0.5em] \sqrt{x^3}\cdot\sqrt{8}&=8\tag{\,cancel $\sqrt{27}$} \\[0.5em] \sqrt{x^3}&=\dfrac{8}{8^{1/2}}\nonumber \\[0.5em] \sqrt{x^3}&=\sqrt{8}\tag{\,Using Law 2} \\[0.5em] \end{align*}\] Finally, switch back to \(2^3\) \[\begin{align*} x^3&=8=2^3 \end{align*}\]

So x=2

Quick check problems

  1. What is the singular of indices?

Answer:

  1. Solve \(3x^3\cdot 5=45\) for x

Answer: x equals

  1. Determine whether the following calculations are correct:

  1. \(\dfrac{3x^a}{y^{8b}}\cdot\dfrac{4z^a}{y^{d}}= \dfrac{12(xz)^a}{y^{d+8b}}\)

  2. \(\dfrac{4^2}{2^4}=2\)

  3. \((7^2)^0=1\)

  4. \(x^2+x^3\) is greater than \(x\) for all values of \(x\)
